Expectation1: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation1: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I glance at the clock as I finish my errands, realizing how late it’s gotten. Sunday afternoons always slip away faster than I expect. My church’s evening service starts soon, and I promised myself I’d go this week—I’ve missed too many lately, and I know how much it means to my faith and to the friends who keep asking about me. But today is also election day, and the polling station closes in just a couple of hours. I can’t shake the sense of duty to vote; it’s a responsibility I take seriously, a way to shape the world I live in. My pastor always says to be a light in the world, but what does that mean right now? If I go to church, I might not make it to the polls in time. If I vote first, I’ll miss the worship and the fellowship I’ve been craving. My heart pounds as I sit in my car, torn between two callings, both important, both urgent, and I wonder which part of myself I’ll have to disappoint tonight.
